turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Salvatore Falcone and Joseph Falcone versus Harold E. Barnes, Officer in Charge of Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Mr. Fay.
The counsel sitting in the rear of the room, please refrain from disturbing the Court, this is not a conference room and there is a place for that for the lawyers, please.
You may proceed Mr. Fay.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: May it please the Court.
This case is the companion case of United States versus Minker.
The questions are similar to the questions presented in that case.
The facts in the instant case might be briefly examined before and claim into my argument.
The two petitioners here, Salvatore and Joseph Falcone, were brothers.
They were born in Italy and immigrated to this country in 1907 with their parents.
They were naturalized in the courts of the State of New York in 1925.
They continued to live in this country thereafter.
In 1952, the petitioner, Salvatore Falcone, was residing in Florida.
He was away from the city and his residence at the time when an immigration officer visited there and left words that when he returned, he should report to the immigration office.
He voluntarily went down upon his returning to the city.
He submitted -- he was informed that a charge have been made against him that he was an alien.
He submitted his naturalization certificate and at that time, he answered all questions that were propounded to him by this hearing officer.
Seven months later, he received a letter from the immigration office, telling him to come in again and to bring with him his naturalization certificate on an official manner.
He again appeared, tendered his certificates and answered all questions that were propounded to him at that time by the immigration officer.
Simultaneously in Utica, New York, his brother, petitioner Joseph, had received an identical letter for his appearance at the Utica office on the same day that Salvatore was appearing in Florida.
He also appeared.
He appeared with counsel and propounded to question to the examiner as to the purpose of the inquiry.
He was refused any explanation.
And on the advice of counsel, he refused to make a statement as requested by the hearing officer.

Two months later in June of 1953, the petitioner Joseph Falcone was served with a subpoena in a nature of the subpoena duces tecum to bring with him his certificate of naturalization, his birth certificate, and his certificate of entry to this country.
He again appeared at the office of Immigration Service with counsel.
Counsel, at that time, informed the hearing officer that they were appearing specially to question the validity of the subpoena with respect to its direction against a citizen of this country.
At the same time, counsel voluntarily submitted for examination, aside from the subpoena, the certificates of naturalization, original entry and birth certificate.
But after further questioning by the hearing officer and the insistence on counsel that the petitioner Joseph should not answer the questions, the hearing was terminated.
At that stage, the counsel for petitioner, Joseph Falcone, asked if he could have the right to purchase a transcript of the stenographic notes that were taken at the hearing.
He was refused that right on the grounds that they were confidential records of the United States Government.
It couldn't be furnished to him.
Ten days later, his brother, petitioner Salvatore, received an identical subpoena.
The Court already knows how that subpoena is worded, in re Salvatore Falcone.
No explanation on the face of the subpoena as to the purpose or the nature of the investigation.
He also appeared at the office with counsel and raised a special plea as to the jurisdiction of the immigration officer to subpoena him there for questioning.
He too, tendered his naturalization certificate to prove that he was a citizen.
Thereafter, in September of 1953, the United States Attorney moved in District Court for an order to show cause why this subpoena should not be enforced.
There was a hearing before District Court Judge Foley in Utica, New York.
The evidence was all presented and Judge Foley ruled at that time and his opinion appears at page 26 of the transcript of the record in number 47.
Judge Foley refused to enforce these subpoenas.

And he predicated his refusal, "On the ground that the limitation of this administrative subpoena power in my judgment must be kept within the confines of the provisions as stated and restricted to such purpose.
And there's not the slightest indication in the legislative background, nor the terms of the provisions that it may be used for the investigative purpose here sought against a naturalized citizen."
The language appearing on page 32 of the record.

Then going over to page 34, he concluded that if the subpoena here were allowed to stand, the judicial procedure for the -- revocation of naturalization certificates would be preempted by administrative action.
And the provisions for personal notice, 60-day time period to answer in Section 340 (a) of the Act would be empty words.
Thus, it's apparent that the facts in the instant case differ slightly from those in the Minker case.
Here, there was compliance by these two citizens with this form of command that was issued by the immigration service.
In the Minker case, it was a motion to crush the subpoena which ended in a contempt citation when the respondent refused to appear as ordered by the District Court.
This case was taken by the Government to the Second Circuit.
And that circuit ruled that the District Court was wrong in deciding that the subpoena should not be enforced.

And the circuit predicated its decision on the fact that the arm of the Immigration and Naturalization Service would be strengthened if the court was to read a broad interpretation into the language of Section 235 (a), and that the Immigration Service would more readily be in a good position to fair it out subversives or those who were seeking under a cloak of recent citizenship to do injury to our Government.

They've conceded as the record compel them to do so that there was no evidence or even any inference that the petitioners, Salvatore or Joseph Falcone, had any knowledge of or any participation in -- subversive activities of any kind whatsoever.

Now, counsel for the respondent Minker has dwelt on the internal construction of Section 235 (a) and of the Act as a whole as a guide for the interpretation of the power that Congress intended to give the administrative agency by the words which have been added to Section 235 (a).
Counsel pointed out that in changing the word person from alien, there was no intent to enlarge it to the extent that would include citizen.

That in using the word privilege, the Congress amply used the word that necessarily applies to the position of the alien as he stands in this country but has no reference whatsoever to the position of the citizen who certainly has a right, not a privilege to reside in the United States.

And finally, that the word witness as used by the Congress in the statute didn't necessarily in its common accepted terms and certainly in this field of an area of privacy much more restricted than in regulatory statutes or economic activities of business.
And that accordingly, that Congress never intended the word witness to mean a party who would be subject to a revocation act at a later day.
Finally, respondent counsel has argued a reasonable interpretation of Section 235 that necessarily would result in a restrictive use of that particular proviso.

Petitioner now, assuming that Section 235 (a) is as broad as the Government contends, would like to point out the power that necessarily flows from such an interpretation into the evasion of the privacy of citizens.
There was mentioned in the fact that there are over 8 million naturalized citizens in this country.
It seems not unreasonable to plea.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: The Act -- the Act applies to every citizen of the United States, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Well, counsel --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: If they're -- if they're naturalized or natural born.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Well, if the broadest interpretation was given to the words, it could be conceivably extended to that extent.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Why --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: -- it's simply that --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- it could practically be extended to that extent, Your Honor, yes.
But as a practical matter in the concept of what Congress was dealing with here, namely, the --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Investigatory --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- naturalization certificates of citizens who acquired it by naturalization, I suppose to the natural-born citizen.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I've seen -- I've seen very serious discussion whether Governor, certainly not participating having been born in Paris.
But he stated specifically in connection with possibilities and to -- would you mind telling us.
I mean is --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: It --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- Justice Reed right about it, as in questions whether --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: It is conceivable that this statute --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.(Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- can be used to subpoena him.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Might have been in Paris, his origin for naturalized citizens brought as a child.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: And if this Section 235 is given the broad contention that the Government claims for it, it is quite possible that he could be subpoenaed to answer that query.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Just as every citizen could before the Congress of the United States.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I believe, yes.

But I draw a distinction between the power that the Congress of the United States has intrinsically from the Constitution to subpoena in relation to its investigatory power as to the power which they in turn can delegate to administrative agencies that might invade other constitutional rights of the individual.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: That's the Constitution is made of.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I'm sorry, sir?

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: That's the Constitution made.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Thank you, sir.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Just to say, those citizens, if this subpoena this -- subpoena these witnesses.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I'm sorry, I missed the first part of your sentence Mr. Justice Clark.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Say the citizens, would you say that be subpoenaed in the act to be there as witness if they would not be there as parties.
You can't denaturalize the natural-born citizens.
You couldn't have it just as citizen, a natural-born citizen would be comparable to this one.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I think the distinction is well taken, Your Honor, but I still believe that under the -- the 235 (a), have given the broad construction contended for by the Government that the citizen, whether a natural -- denaturalized or American born, would be subject to the subpoena and would have to come in to prove his naturalization status or his native-born status.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, I thought that the counsel on the previous case, as based on his fact, here you're bringing in the party to which the -- more than the fact that he's a citizen.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Well, I feel that the counsel for respondent did point out to the Court the difference between the consequences of the use of the word witness in its normal accepted things which excludes a party in the sense that he is going to be the object of an action of the same antagonist that's bringing the action against him in the subpoena form.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well they couldn't bring an action against him, could they?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Immigration --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- I said only in the subpoena form, Your Honor.
I was using the term --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- action in the sense that they were directing the subpoena to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there any indication -- are there -- there maybe in this Act that the word witness was intended to be used broad enough to cover any person, accept one summon to participate as a witness in some kind of hearing that was authorized by law.
I mean the statute because I haven't read the (Inaudible)
But the witness says I have always understood it, generally referred to a person summoned to give testimony in some kind of hearing, either administrative or -- or judicial.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is petitioner's concept --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If the FBI --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- of the word used.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If the FBI finds and it summons somebody and notify them to appear before them, are they witnesses within the general meaning of the term if they want to make an investigation?
Notify somebody to appear before them, do they -- do they appear as witnesses or do they appear just because they're notified?
The word here --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- we have is witnesses.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything that indicates in this Act that persons are -- are to be classified as witnesses, were asked to do nothing but come and give as some kind of evidence not in a hearing of any kind but to be used by some kind of executive agents here to get some kind of proof to be used in some hearing conducted somewhere else.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I don't think that that thought which Your Honor expresses is spelled out any place in its eye.

But from the standpoint of construction, petitioner certainly contend that the word witnesses would mean someone who is capable of having knowledge of an act that is to be used against another party, not the sense that it is a party to the act.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well I'm talking -- I'm talking about the kind of place, they are summoned to talk in.

Either this is a -- the word witness usually limited to one who's notified to appear and give evidence or testimony in a proceeding or is it -- does it include generally people who are notified to appear before an executive agent and share for deputy share of FBI or someone, simply to give them some information so that they can use it in connection with use -- getting them later to serve as witnesses in a hearing which is -- which isn't used there.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I think, Your Honor, that it can -- it is capable of being used in both senses.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You do?

Now, which part of this Act gives the authority to summon a witness, call a person a witness who is merely to give information to be used by an executive officer who has no authority to conduct the hearing?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: The use of the word in Section 235 (a) at the bottom of page 652 of the Governments brief, in case number 35.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No, I had -- I had your brief here (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor but --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Bottom of Page 60.
I -- I don't know which part is it --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Yes, it may be also quoted in petitioner's brief in this case but I had just used the reference to the Government's brief in the previous case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: 235 in your brief at page 60.
Now, to do any petition for certiorari --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I'm sorry -- page 60.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, which part --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Page 61, Your Honor.

At the middle of the page, "The Attorney General and any -- any immigration officer including special inquiry officers shall have power to require by a subpoena the attendance and testimony of witnesses before immigration officer."

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Before immigration officers.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: And special inquiry officers, yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: To do what now, concerning what?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: "And the production of books, paper, and documents relating to the privilege of any person to enter, reenter, reside in or pass through the United States."
And the new language which was added begins after the word United States.
Prior to the Act of 1952, that was the extent of the subpoena power with a little different change in wording.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, the --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: But Congress added --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- if the agency given them power in the Act to hold hearings in connection with those who enter, reenter, reside in, or pass through the United States.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Under the first part of the Section 235, the -- the inspection other than the physical and mental examination of aliens, seeking and measured for readmission to or the privilege of passing through shall be conducted by immigration officers except as -- otherwise regard -- provided in regard to special inquiry.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are they authorized and to hold those hearings with reference to that?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That's correct sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But were they authorized the hold hearings with reference to denaturalizing citizens?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: We contend they are not, sir.
And that the only place for such authority is in the third part of the Act, that Congress segregated it into two or three parts.
The second part dealing with entry and exclusions, the third part of the Act which contains Section 340 (a) dealing with naturalized citizens or other citizens who might be suspected of being aliens.
But we contend that there is nothing in the second part of this Act and certainly not in Section 235 (a) that gives them the right to subpoena the citizen in court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, they have final power, do they not?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: How was that sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They have final power to hold hearings and conducts here investigative hearings to reach a final decision subject to courts to such judicial reviews it has concerning all of these matters here that aliens residing in and so forth that are mentioned.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I believe so, Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But they do not have any power at all with reference to denaturalizing citizens.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is our contention, sir, yes.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Who makes the -- who -- who furnishes the information to the District Attorney --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: -- to the procedings they brought?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- the Immigration Service is supposed to present to him sufficient evidence in the form of an affidavit to show cause.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: This investigation is to get that evidence, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: It well maybe, Your Honor, but the petitioner's contention is that the evidence should not be obtained by the subpoena to the party against whom the evidence is going to be used.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: I understand that but this particular exception, 235 (a), is intended to give an opportunity for the Immigration Service to gather the evidence that they're going to present to the District Attorney, isn't it?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I'm not even confident, Your Honor, that the language is broad enough to sustain that proposition.
And that the -- any investigation with relation -- as far as the subpoena power is concerned now only.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: That's what they thought.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: In other words, it's our contention that the service has the right to investigate and to secure evidence the same as other investigative forces do without subpoena power and submit that to the United States Attorney.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, that's this section does purport to arrange for the Immigration Service to gather evidence.
I'm not using the word subpoena.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: All right, sir, yes.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: In order to submit it to the United States Attorney, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: It's capable of the interpretation, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where does it say that?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Specifically?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I don't believe that there is any specific language.
I merely suggested it was capable of the interpretation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's same thing to be said about the FBI, wasn't it?
They are -- they are supposed to get up the information and give to the -- to the -- for the enforcement of that law and whether it's all of it.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Justice Black, yes.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: There is a subpoena section, isn't it, Mr. Fay, in section -- page 66 of your petition for a writ of certiorari, Section 287, part four.
Then you may ask and the words only says, they may issue be as advised, this in connection.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Those are the instructions listed by the Attorney General, sir.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Not -- not any other -- not any overruling statute to give the FBI the power to subpoena, isn't it?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: No, there is not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But is this a statute?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: No, Your Honor, this is a code of regulations as Mr. Justice Clark --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On Page 66, that's the Attorney General's order --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that's --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: He --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- not a statute.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: No sir.
No, 287.4 related to the subpoena power and who may issue.
It is the regulation promulgated by the Attorney General and submitted then.
But even at that --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: You don't attack that --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: -- regulation, do you?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I'm sorry Your Honor?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: You don't attack that regulation and you think it --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: As applied to the citizen, yes, but I don't think there's any language in 287.4 that makes a reference to the citizens, sir.
It requires primarily to the alien and the word issues throughout alien, and as used.
And it has reference to part two of the Act which again deals with entry and exclusion and not with naturalized citizens.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: If that's in any proceedings, you have to say that investigation to given that denaturalization without proceeding, I suppose.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Under the second part of the Act until it -- we proceed in the -- the Court under the third part of the Act.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: As I read the stipulation though that alien from any party which is interested in the proceeding would issue a subpoena, rather asks for expedition as part of this directly -- and directly to manage himself.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: But petitioner maintains that that is in proceeding relative to entry or exclusion in the dealing he gave them.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does that purport to give the immigration officers any authority to denaturalize citizens or to try cases against them in any way and to hold hearings against them?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I don't think that there's any language that could be so construed, Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: The only thing and definitely thing it's said on then -- you can -- would be in order to find this at all or determine whether is at all --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Justice Clark.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Whether if you'd file -- filing the suit in court.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Well, they' all require to have the affidavit of good cause before filing a suit.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Is this, Mr. Fay, the nature of grand jury proceeding?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: There is under the interpretation that the Government is asking for.

It certainly has like a relationship to it and I'd like to point out that -- I believe the -- the consequences that flow from this power, if it is once conceded to exist by this Court, such as the Government contends, is best illustrated by the facts in this case.
Here, these petitioners had three appearances before an immigration officer.
There was no notice in the subpoena as to the purpose of the investigation.
They asked for the notice that are -- they asked for the purpose of itt

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Then they have three subpoenas?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: No sir, not three subpoenas, three appearances, I say, Mr. Justice Reed.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, they were voluntary, weren't they?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: The first two were in compliance with an oral request, a written letter and finally the subpoena.

But they asked for the purpose of the investigation and we're refused any explanation which leads petitioner to believe that even on the face of the subpoena, it might be subject to the possible construction that they were without jurisdiction and that they were relying on the broader language for denaturalization or revocation which is incorporated in the Act of 1952, but was not in the law at the time these petitioners received their naturalization certificate.
Congress did broaden the field upon which you could denaturalize a person in this Act of 1952.
When they said it no longer has to be for fraud, it can merely be for a material concealment or a willful misrepresentation --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When they --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- not even of a material mind.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought they were broadening it.
Did they indicate in any way that the immigration department could conduct the hearings, preliminary hearings or any other kind?

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: There is no word in the statute that I can say that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If had a duty, I suppose, it's like the duty of the sheriff and policeman and the FBI to get at aliens.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is our concept, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And I do not suppose that the fact here usually look to deputy sheriffs and policemen, required warrants and find a good cause would -- would authorize them ordinarily without statutory authority to summon people to testify before them.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I can't conceive of it, Your Honor, no.
Finally, all of these undesirable consequences can be eliminated if the construction is placed on this 235 (a) by this Court.
That if -- to follow that, of Judge Foley, that it was never conceived by Congress that it should be used against the citizen and restrict the sole method of procedure to 340 (a) under part three.
In addition, the cases which the Government cites that petitioner contends are not authority for the invasion of privacy that would result from the issuance of this subpoena here.
Their cases involve primarily economic activities.
They're directed against corporate entities, usually records of the object of the subpoena.

Witnesses are usually officers or sole proprietors of business who are coming in to testify about the activities of their business which the petitioner concedes that the administrative agencies can regulate.
Finally, in some other cases, the witness is an alien rather than a citizen.

And the petitioner can -- is convinced that there is a substantial difference between the two with rare exception of every one of the statutes, as outlined in Shapiro v. United States that contained this subpoena power, also contain an immunity clause and it's significant here that Congress didn't immunize the citizen against any testimony he might give under compulsion.
Contracts then, the corporate entity with the individual, the regulatory problem against the prosecution of the individual in trying to take a certificate away from him.
The current activities to the remote past event here of one item of alleged misstatement of fact or a concealment.
And finally, the production of records against that vital difference of oral testimony.

It seems to petitioner that Congress would have spoken pretty emphatically and unclearly if it had any knowledge that the Immigration Service had an intention that Section 235 (a) or the new language that was to be added to that old section that now becomes 235 (a) was to be used against the naturalized citizens.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You do -- you do not deny that Congress has authorized the immigration officers to conduct an investigation upon which an affidavit might be made to in -- to give to the Attorney General upon which he may base a proceeding to cancel.
You do not deny that -- that's sort of an investigation is authorized.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: I think inherently the Immigration Service has the right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you say that that -- do you say that that's not a proceeding in which the subpoena can be used against the person being investigated as a witness.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Or you or anybody.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Or anybody.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But what you have said -- or indeed anybody --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Or indeed anybody but certainly, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, not against the subject who is going to be -- in effect the defendant in a proceeding shortly thereafter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Your argument isn't one thing for Congress to define explicitly or perhaps the best to authorize an official like the Attorney General by a regulation to set up an investigatory process --

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- by another source.
Or officer of United States in charge of investigating whatever it is.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then you come and talk to him.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't have to talk to him because I don't want to.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: That is our understanding of the American --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's your -- that's your argument.

turn.speaker: george_morris_fay
turn.label: Mr. George Morris Fay
turn.text: -- of -- of the American way of life.

And I think it's best exemplified by Mr. Justice -- Chief Justice Hughes' opinion in the Macintosh case there where he concluded that if there are two possible interpretations that can be given to the Act, the one most hospitable to the citizen should be the one that we would see.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Frankel.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: May it please the Court.
I want to address myself first to the question that's been discussed at some length in both Mr. Kossman's argument and Mr. Fay's argument.
The answer -- our answer to which I would put this way.

In the administrative subpoena power, the administrative investigative subpoena power, as it is grown up over the long years, there is no necessity in order to find such a power that there'll be a power of hearing or adjudication on the subject matter to which the power relates.
That's a long sentence and let me try to explicate it.
The administrator, the wage -- the administrator has clearly a subpoena power, the power that was before this Court in Oklahoma Press Publishing Company against Walling.
He uses the subpoena power as the Court knows to get facts to determine whether he will bring an action in court.
He has no power himself, although it has been urged that he ought to have to adjudicate the subject as to which he investigates and for which this Court has upheld his subpoena power.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he has -- the -- the investigation may result in conclusions which are duly here and which would duly notify -- would be before us.
And the only thing is this one, the thing gets to court, is that right?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well, it depends, Your Honors.
Of some of these investigations, criminal prosecutions result.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm not -- I'm -- I'm not deny -- I'm not denying what you refer.
I'm merely questioning what you deny to be sure from in criminal prosecution.

But am I wrong in saying that with one exception about which I'm not informed, and you tell me, every blessed one of the investigative subpoena provisions included on your page 41, relate to agencies.

I take it, none of which under the Humphrey doctrine, members of none of which could be dismissed by a person the United States in the Humphrey doctrine against an act of congress in giving (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If that was so, they all have --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I don't think so, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I don't think so.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You don't.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: For one --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, let's have a great provision listed down the line.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well, can I name two or three that -- that answers that?
The Veterans Administrator.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well that, I -- I --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: The Social Security Administrator.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not -- I hope --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Oh.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- you don't mind that.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: There are exceptions, I'm sorry, I misunderstood.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I have said with the exception of the Veterans Administrator about which I don't know and about -- actually, you might be right.
I'm not sure, I'm not sure but -- or all the evidence, I should think formal in the Humphrey doctrine.
Look at Federal Trade Commission, security exchange for the holding company, I don't throw in that like interrelations act.
They're all agencies of very considerable administrative distinction.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Yes of course, Your --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Who --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: -- Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- all of which -- all of which have so-called quasi adjudicatory functions, am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well, sir, you're -- you're wrong about some of them and -- and that's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, not may be decides -- may be Veteran Administration in your brief to 41, the page 41 which are not.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well, the -- the administrator of the Fair Labor Standards Act has the subpoena power with respect to matters as to which he does not have adjudicating power.
Now, let me say --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: -- this one further thing.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) -- that's the one.
It may be a --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: This footnote -- this footnote, Your Honor, was not written for this purpose.
I would like permission to go beyond --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: -- this footnote.
The --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's an impressive footnote, but when I came to think about it, it means the -- the -- appears in my mind, the distinction I'm trying to make that these are very different bodies with very different functions, although of course, as to each one, criminal statutes are probably in the statutes which would require initiation of the court.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: These -- the -- the narrow point I'm making is that the scope of the subpoena power has never, to my knowledge, been measured by the scope of the adjudicating power.
And it is no answer to our argument, as I see it, that the subpoena power is available for the purposes we assert here to say that this is not a subject on which the Attorney General can adjudicate.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If you can -- if you can find specific language in the Act like that, that I think is still is, the Fair Labor Standards Act, I have some recollections there.
And I think it's very, very, very specific to amend investigatory power as to what it -- what they'd investigate.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Unfortunately I -- I didn't copy out the language of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
Let me read the language of the Veterans Pension Act.
It says, "For the purposes of the laws administered by the Veterans Administration, there shall be a power to subpoena witnesses."

Now, it's been held and I think it falls squarely within that language that schools, taking money from veterans under the G.I. bills can be investigated and are subject to that subpoena power of the Veterans Administrator when he's inquiring, whether there maybe civil or criminal fraud in their use of Government money through the G.I. bill.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is he charged with the responsibility of initiating proceedings where he finds wrong doing?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well, the way -- the way these matters work --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, I'm -- I'm asking the -- I'm asking about the Veterans' Administrator.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: He would refer them to the Attorney General, Your Honor.
Just as --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
How about the -- how about the administrator of affair -- of the wage and labor with the power.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: He would refer criminal prosecutions to the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He wouldn't do that, would he not, under the specific command of the Act?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I believe so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any such command in this Act?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: The command of this Act is that the Attorney General is charged with the enforcement of all the provisions of this Act.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does that mean the naturalization commissioner?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I -- that means the Attorney General and with appropriate delegations which are authorized by the statute, his delegee.
Now, I think it should be born in mind that 235 (a), the provision we're discussing here, refers to the Attorney General and any immigration officer.

It gives this subpoena power in terms, unlike the old 1917 Act to the Attorney General whose powers and responsibilities are -- and this, I think, is quite undisputed, coextensive with this Act with its civil and criminal provisions.
Now, I think it's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You are speaking of whom now, the -- the Attorney General or the Commissioner?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Pardon, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You're speaking of whom, the Attorney General?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: The Attorney General.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but that isn't the question.
It isn't the Attorney General who has subpoenaed this man, is it?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well the Attorney General has broad powers of delegation under the Act.
These people were subpoenaed by a District Director --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where -- where is that, this having power.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: In Section 103 (a), Your Honor.
I believe it's 103 (a) 18.
No, it's 103 (a).
It says "The Attorney General shall be charged with the administration and enforcement of this Act and all other laws relating to the immigration and naturalization of alien".

Then down below, it said "He is authorized to appoint employees and to delegate to them or any officer or employee of the Department of Justice in his discretion any of the duties and powers imposed upon him by this Act."
There's no question of the due delegation of the subpoena power in the regulations that were discussed by Mr. Fay with Mr. Justice Clark.
And there is no question, I think, that for purposes of the statutory construction problem before the Court, it's the same as if this subpoena had been issued by the Attorney General.
This is a function of the Attorney General being performed with no question as to the propriety and the delegation by his duly authorized and barely high ranking subordinate.

Now, I say and it's hard to demonstrate this briefly but I believe it's clear that the administrative investigative power as it has for years and coupled with the subpoena power, has never been restricted to the areas where the administrative authority can make an adjudication.
Now, I think this Act, Section 235 (a), appropriately reflects that proposition which I had thought was clear.
After conferring the subpoena power -- I'm now referring to page 53 of the Government's brief in the Minker case, the case preceding this one.
After referring or granting the subpoena power, for purposes of any matter which is material and relevant to the enforcement of this Act and the administration of the service.
The Act goes on to provide an enforcement power in the District Court.

And the next sentence says, "Any United States District Court within the jurisdiction of which investigations or inquiries are being conducted," and then it goes on to provide for their enforcement of this subpoena.
Now this, I submit, is part of a familiar pattern.

This pattern of administrative subpoena for investigative purposes, not linked to or limited by the scope of the adjudicating power that the agency may have Mr. Justice Cardozo said, the investigations, these administrative investigations, armed with the subpoena power are quite appropriate even where their objective may be to turn up material for criminal prosecution.
And it's clear that the agencies that have this subpoena power do not have the power to conduct criminal prosecutions.

And so here, I say the fact that the Attorney General is only given the power and duty to enforce the revocation provisions in court is no reason for denying his subpoena power but as part of a very old scheme, is appropriate reason to grant it to him when Congress had spoken as we think so clearly.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, if -- but it does have to speak clearly, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
And now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Now, I want to go to those words again and see how clear they are in the light of the time, the circumstances and the personnel who wrote it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Frankel, before you get to that, may I ask just one question to get to your position clear.
Let's take an entirely different field from immigration.
But a field over which the Attorney General has a jurisdiction or investigating and initiating prosecutions or -- or some kind of civil action.

Would he have the right to delegate to the FBI, for instance, the right to issue subpoenas and compel people to come in and testify before that agency in the absence of specific language authorizing him to do so?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If -- well, then you --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well, we may -- we may wind up quarreling about the phrase -- the word specific but he needs statutory authority --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: -- to do that, we concede.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, how do you distinguish that clearly from this situation that we have here?
If -- if the Naturalization Act does not give the Immigration Commissioner jurisdiction over the denaturalization of citizens.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I -- I think when I read what you rather quickly, I may have misunderstood your question, Mr. Chief Justice.
I think you cannot have the subpoena power without statutory authorization.
Our issue here is, "Do we have the statutory authorization for the kind of subpoena power we have asserted?"

Now, my further point is that when you're construing a statute like this which grants the subpoena power, it is not a valid argument to say this subpoena power doesn't extend to subject X because as to subject X, you don't have any adjudicating power.

I am saying that Congress, over and over again, has given a power of investigation coupled with a subpoena power relating to questions as to which the particular official could not adjudicate but could only bring an action in Court if his investigation turned up immaterial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
And now that --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: And the stautute contemplates just that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's the point where -- that's the point where -- where we -- we break.
Does the Commissioner of immigration have the right to initiate a proceeding for denaturalization?
If you -- if you tell me that he does, that will solve a great problem for me but in the absence of such a right, I'm in trouble on this one.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Well, I want to tell you two things very quickly, if I may.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I want to tell you first that the Attorney General has the duty and the power to initiate denaturalization proceedings in the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll see.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: And then I want to say that this subpoena power that we're concerned with here is the Attorney General's subpoena power.
Now, the fact that the Attorney General doesn't run around the country and serve subpoenas or even sign them, has never been a material issue in this case.
It's clear under the Act, and nobody has quarreled with us, that he can delegate that power.
In 8 CFR, 287.4, which was discussed with Mr. Justice Clark, that new delegation has been made.

So what we say is, that this is clearly a matter material and relevant in the enforcement of this Act which is one, the kind of matter for which the Attorney General is responsible, and two, the kind of matter as to which he has been given the subpoena power subject to appropriate delegation.
Now, I want to talk about this language and try to make our point that it clearly covers this kind of subpoena.
The language says, the subpoena may be used concerning any matter which is material and relevant to the enforcement of this Act.
Now, Mr. --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It has something before that though --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it does.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- and that we put the Attorney General which the Immigration Department has a great deal of power.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: That's right and I -- if -- if our skip -- skip has been too slippery, I want to apologize, we didn't intend it that way.
But we do intend --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) notice they -- you -- it might en jeopardize any projection of fore findings?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: No, I -- I was just touched by the description of our asterisk but they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the Government --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: -- we've never thought of them in quite that powerful way and -- and I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Maybe even more careful next time.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: What I want to say about this language is this.
This language was deliberately and purposefully added to the former subpoena provision.

When Mr. Kossman says, "It would be fine to compare this language with other general subpoena power language which it precisely resembles, he largely, we think, concedes our case because this language wasn't just an old thing that was slipped in at some prior time but the attention of Congress was focused precisely on this new additional broad clause.
Now, what did the Congress revoke to the 1952 Act, think of when it thought of matters which are material and relevant to the enforcement of this Act.
What's our evidence?
The Senate Committee listed six broad, overall significant achievements of the 1952 Act.
One of them was, that the Act heightened up and made more stringent the naturalization and denaturalization provisions.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There are a lot of stuff in the provision which cover that.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: There's only one -- well there are a lot of provisions.
But when I -- what I'm saying now is this.
This is plain language.
Denaturalization is in plain language material and relevant.
Now, the question is, "Should we take it out or should we leave it in?"

And we say that when this Congress thought of what was material and relevant in the enforcement of this Act, when it thought of the hardcore of essential functions of the Immigration Service, one of the few things you would immediately think of is denaturalization.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it's strange if you would speak of it of merely -- gives some other influence to follow enforcement.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: Not in this amendment.
No instances were given.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, I didn't mean the amendments and what it said about and what we -- but the service wouldn't think of it.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: They gave an example.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: They gave an example.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well it's --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: And they gave an example that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, yes but this is the obvious one in the Act as to your subversive pursuance, Judge Medina, preoccupation depriving of the department and occasionally about it.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I'm not saying this was a preoccupation, if you please.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm suggesting that --

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: I'm saying that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- of his preoccupation.

turn.speaker: marvin_e_frankel
turn.label: Mr. Marvin E. Frankel
turn.text: We are concerned not with the particular example that the Immigration and natural -- Naturalization Service gave, although, note, that it's an example, it doesn't relate to an alien and doesn't relate to deportation or exclusion.
